pr_title: Resolves #928: support edge ordering in planner graphs

timeline.body:
I think this needs some explanation for why a `PlannerExpression` might want to "rewrite" its graph. I think I understand why (namely, to be able to replace higher-order structures with simpler/more insightful representations), but it took me a long time to understand this.

One thing I'm still not sure about: why is this done by having the `PlannerExpression` do the rewriting, rather than having some "rules" that do the rewriting (in line with the design of the rule-based planner itself)? I think the answer is "to avoid doing `instanceof` checking in some utility class", but I wanted to double-check.
timeline.bodyText:

One thing I'm still not sure about: why is this done by having the PlannerExpression do the rewriting, rather than having some "rules" that do the rewriting (in line with the design of the rule-based planner itself)? I think the answer is "to avoid doing instanceof checking in some utility class", but I wanted to double-check.
timeline.bodyHTML:
I think this needs some explanation for why a PlannerExpression might want to "rewrite" its graph. I think I understand why (namely, to be able to replace higher-order structures with simpler/more insightful representations), but it took me a long time to understand this.

One thing I'm still not sure about: why is this done by having the PlannerExpression do the rewriting, rather than having some "rules" that do the rewriting (in line with the design of the rule-based planner itself)? I think the answer is "to avoid doing instanceof checking in some utility class", but I wanted to double-check.

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
// If the current node had children that explicitly encode an order we do the following:
// We create a sub-block and set rank=same, rankDir=LR in order to have all children be rendered
// on the same level but left to right -- this is especially important for showing join-orders
// left-to-right.
// If the current node had children that explicitly encode an order we do the following:
// We create a sub-block and set rank=same, rankDir=LR in order to have all children be rendered
// on the same level but left to right.
// This is especially important for showing join-orders left-to-right.
timeline.author: nschiefer

timeline.bodyHTML:
If we keep this general block of code, I think this is more in line with our style guide:

Suggested change
for (; index < orderedChildrenEdges.size(); index ++) {
final E currentEdge = orderedChildrenEdges.get(index);
if (!dependsOn.contains(currentEdge)) {
break;
}
}
while (index < orderedChildrenEdges.size()) {
final E currentEdge = orderedChildrenEdges.get(index);
if (!dependsOn.contains(currentEdge)) {
break;
}
index++;
}

timeline.body: I think that this needs a detailed Javadoc explaining what it does (and especially what `childGraphs` is). In particular, this is important because the interface shows up in so many `RecordQueryPlan` implementations.

timeline.body: I think that these implementations are quite hard to read without a lot of derails about how the `InternalPlannerGraph`-related classes work. For each of them, perhaps a brief Javadoc can summarize the "intent" (e.g., "Display an IN-join plan in the style of nested loop join...")?
timeline.bodyText: I think that these implementations are quite hard to read without a lot of derails about how the InternalPlannerGraph-related classes work. For each of them, perhaps a brief Javadoc can summarize the "intent" (e.g., "Display an IN-join plan in the style of nested loop join...")?
timeline.bodyHTML: I think that these implementations are quite hard to read without a lot of derails about how the InternalPlannerGraph-related classes work. For each of them, perhaps a brief Javadoc can summarize the "intent" (e.g., "Display an IN-join plan in the style of nested loop join...")?
timeline.author: nschiefer

timeline.body:
The amount of code duplication between `rewriteInternalPlannerGraph()` and `rewriteExplainPlannerGraph()` is quite unfortunate. I assume it's tricky to make this better because of the type system? Unless we can think of a fundamental reason to change it, we should open an issue about cleaning this up (but I won't block the merge on resolving this).

This close relationship seems to hold for (almost?) all of the implementations of these methods, which does suggest that something is awry with our abstractions.
timeline.bodyText:
The amount of code duplication between rewriteInternalPlannerGraph() and rewriteExplainPlannerGraph() is quite unfortunate. I assume it's tricky to make this better because of the type system? Unless we can think of a fundamental reason to change it, we should open an issue about cleaning this up (but I won't block the merge on resolving this).
This close relationship seems to hold for (almost?) all of the implementations of these methods, which does suggest that something is awry with our abstractions.
timeline.bodyHTML:
The amount of code duplication between rewriteInternalPlannerGraph() and rewriteExplainPlannerGraph() is quite unfortunate. I assume it's tricky to make this better because of the type system? Unless we can think of a fundamental reason to change it, we should open an issue about cleaning this up (but I won't block the merge on resolving this).

This close relationship seems to hold for (almost?) all of the implementations of these methods, which does suggest that something is awry with our abstractions.
timeline.author: nschiefer

replies.bodyText: I have redesigned this for better code reuse in a way that we can allow for a specific deviation from the common path if explain is different than internal show. If they are the same both use cases now do use the same node and edge hierarchy and can therefore reuse large amounts of code. I am happier with the that than to keep classes strictly separated but also duplicated.
replies.author: normen662

timeline.body: The rewrites with fancy string interpolation stuff are the ones that make me saddest about the code duplication.

replies.bodyText: see above -- no reason to be sad anymore
replies.author: normen662

timeline.body: I think that "invisible edges" are the ones that we add to enforce the ordering convention (e.g., for join order), but I think this is complicated enough that we'll struggle to maintain it without a comment here.

timeline.body:
Probably worth including this explanation from the PR description:
> dot exports use dependsOn() by adding an invisible edge (not to the graph; just to the dot export) between children of a node. It also adds the visual constraint to layout children from left to right

timeline.body:
While we're adding comments, let's say something about what an `Attribute` _is_. Perhaps along the lines of:

```
A tag object that annotates a {@link AbstractPlannerGraph.AbstractNode} or an {@link 

AbstractPlannerGraph.AbstractEdge}, providing additional information to a {@link GraphExporter}.
```

+package com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.temp.explain;
+
+import com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.temp.PlannerExpression;
+
+import javax.annotation.Nonnull;
+import java.util.List;
+
+/**
+ * Interface to allow {@link PlannerExpression}s to rewrite their own
+ * graph representation.
+ *
+ * This interface allows a {@link PlannerExpression} to create/modify low level planner graph structures while
+ * a planner graph is created through an expression walk in {@link PlannerGraphProperty}. Such a rewrite can be useful
+ * if the standard representation is confusing, misleading or just too complicated. For instance,
+ * {@link com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.plans.RecordQueryPlanWithIndex} additionally creates a separate
+ * node underneath the actual plan operator to show the index as a record producer. The nature of the rewrite is
+ * highly operator-specific, therefore, the rewrite is no part of the visitor or some other common logic.

+package com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.temp.explain;
+
+import com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.temp.PlannerExpression;
+
+import javax.annotation.Nonnull;
+import java.util.List;
+
+/**
+ * Interface to allow {@link PlannerExpression}s to rewrite their own
+ * graph representation.
+ *
+ * This interface allows a {@link PlannerExpression} to create/modify low level planner graph structures while
+ * a planner graph is created through an expression walk in {@link PlannerGraphProperty}. Such a rewrite can be useful
+ * if the standard representation is confusing, misleading or just too complicated. For instance,
+ * {@link com.apple.foundationdb.record.query.plan.plans.RecordQueryPlanWithIndex} additionally creates a separate
+ * node underneath the actual plan operator to show the index as a record producer. The nature of the rewrite is
+ * highly operator-specific, therefore, the rewrite is no part of the visitor or some other common logic.
+ * Expressions that decide to implement this interface must then implement {@link #rewritePlannerGraph} to do the
+ * actual rewrite.
+ *
+ * Implementors of this interface will be asked to rewrite the planner graph for both internal show as well as
